capability.description: State machines are simple to understand. There are a number of different state machines, with a range of capabilities. We will now define a particular one, called a Turing machine. As we define "capability", the key is ability, not efficiency.
capability.question: Which of the following relate to the ability of the machine (rather than its efficiency)?
choices: consume small amount of memory as possible

read.description:
The necessary capabilities for any such machine are:
- Read
- Write
- Compute
read.question: Which of these cababilities do NFAs, DFAs, and PDAs have?

tape.description: A Turing machine is defined as follows. It has a one-dimensional tape, divided into squares. This tape extends infinitely to the left and to the right.
tape.question: How many squares does the tape on the left have?

squares.description:
A Turing machine is defined as follows. It has a one-dimensional tape, divided into squares. This tape extends infinitely to the left and to the right.
Each square can store one symbol.
squares.question: How many squares are required to store the string $aaaa$ on the tape?

blank.description:
A Turing machine is defined as follows. It has a one-dimensional tape, divided into squares. This tape extends infinitely to the left and to the right.
Each square can store one symbol.
blank.question: The remaining squares will be marked blank by using the # symbol.

control.description:
A Turing machine is defined as follows. It has a one-dimensional tape, divided into squares. This tape extends infinitely to the left and to the right.
Each square can store one symbol.
The machine has a single I/O head that at any instant in time is "on" one of the squares.
The control unit of the machine is defined by a set of abstract $states$.
control.question: Just like DFAs, NFAs, and PDAs, a convenient way to express the control process is by using a graph with nodes for the states and labels on edges to show the transition rules. How many states does the TM on the left have?

start.description:
A Turing machine is defined as follows. It has a one-dimensional tape, divided into squares. This tape extends infinitely to the left and to the right.
Each square can store one symbol.
The machine has a single I/O head that at any instant in time is "on" one of the squares.
The control unit of the machine is defined by a set of abstract $states$.
At any given instant, the machine is said to be "in" one of the states, and has a set of actions that can be performed when in that state.
start.question: Similar to a DFA, the TM starts in the designated initial state. Which state is this machine in at the start?

first.description:
Since the tape is infinite in both directions, obviously the machine can't start 'at one end'. We use the convention that the TM starts with the tape head at the leftmost non-blank tape cell.
At every cycle, the machine will read the symbol on the current square.
first.question: The machine head will start by reading the current cell's symbol: $a$.

erase.description:
At each step, the machine will read the symbol on the current square, and will then do the following (depending on the value of the symbol that it sees):
1. Overwrite that symbol with a new symbol.
2. Move the tape head either left (L), right (R), or stay put (S).
erase.question: The # symbol means empty cell when it appears on the tape. # in the second position in the transition means to replace the current cell value with #. What will be the new value for the current tape cell in this example?

move.description:
At each step, the machine will read the symbol on the current square, and will then do the following (depending on the value of the symbol that it sees):
1. Overwrite that symbol with a new symbol.
2. Move the tape head either left (L), right (R), or stay put (S).
move.question: What will the head do now in this example?
move.answer: R: go one cell to the right
choices: R: go one cell to the right
L: go one cell to the left
S: stay on the current cell

a2.description:
At each step, the machine will read the symbol on the current square, and will then do the following (depending on the value of the symbol that it sees):
1. Overwrite that symbol with a new symbol.
2. Move the tape head either left (L), right (R), or stay put (S).
a2.question: What will happen next?
a2.answer: Erase the current symbol and go one cell to the right
choices: Erase the current symbol and go one cell to the right
Leave the current symbol and go one cell to the right
Erase the current symbol and go one cell to the left
Leave the current symbol and go one cell to the left
Erase the current symbol and stay at the current cell
Leave the current symbol and stay at the current cell

a3.description:
At each step, the machine will read the symbol on the current square, and will then do the following (depending on the value of the symbol that it sees):
1. Overwrite that symbol with a new symbol.
2. Move the tape head either left (L), right (R), or stay put (S).
a3.question: What will happen next?
a3.answer: Erase the current symbol and go one cell to the right
choices: Erase the current symbol and go one cell to the right
Leave the current symbol and go one cell to the right
Erase the current symbol and go one cell to the left
Leave the current symbol and go one cell to the left
Erase the current symbol and stay at the current cell
Leave the current symbol and stay at the current cell

a4.description:
At each step, the machine will read the symbol on the current square, and will then do the following (depending on the value of the symbol that it sees):
1. Overwrite that symbol with a new symbol.
2. Move the tape head either left (L), right (R), or stay put (S).
a4.question: What will happen next?
a4.answer: Erase the current symbol and go one cell to the right
choices: Erase the current symbol and go one cell to the right
Leave the current symbol and go one cell to the right
Erase the current symbol and go one cell to the left
Leave the current symbol and go one cell to the left
Erase the current symbol and stay at the current cell
Leave the current symbol and stay at the current cell

end.description:
At each step, the machine will read the symbol on the current square, and will then do the following (depending on the value of the symbol that it sees):
1. Overwrite that symbol with a new symbol.
2. Move the tape head either left (L), right (R), or stay put (S).
end.question: What will happen next?
end.answer: Leave the current symbol and stay at the current cell
choices: Erase the current symbol and go one cell to the right
Leave the current symbol and go one cell to the right
Erase the current symbol and go one cell to the left
Leave the current symbol and go one cell to the left
Erase the current symbol and stay at the current cell
Leave the current symbol and stay at the current cell

newstate.description:
At each step, the machine will read the symbol on the current square, and will then do the following (depending on the value of the symbol that it sees):
1. Overwrite that symbol with a new symbol.
2. Move the tape head either left (L), right (R), or stay put (S).
newstate.question: What state should the machine be in now?

definition.description: A Turing machine is formally defined as $(Q, \Sigma, \Gamma, q_0, F, \delta)$.
definition.question: This definition is pretty similar to how we define DFAs, NFAs, PDAs, and grammars. What is $Q$?

F.description: A Turing machine is formally defined as $(Q, \Sigma, \Gamma, q_0, F, \delta)$.
F.question: What is $F$?

q1.description: A Turing machine is formally defined as $(Q, \Sigma, \Gamma, q_0, F, \delta)$.
q1.question: What is the value of $F$ for the machine on the left?

delta.description: A Turing machine is formally defined as $(Q, \Sigma, \Gamma, q_0, F, \delta)$.
delta.question: What is $\delta$?

partin.description: A Turing machine is formally defined as $(Q, \Sigma, \Gamma, q_0, F, \delta)$.
partin.question: $\delta$ is a partial function from $Q \times \Gamma$ to $Q \times \Gamma \times \{L, R, S\})$. This means that the $\delta$ function takes the current state and the current tape symbol as parameters.

partout.description: A Turing machine is formally defined as $(Q, \Sigma, \Gamma, q_0, F, \delta)$.
partout.question: $\delta$ is a partial function from $Q \times \Gamma$ to $Q \times \Gamma \times \{L, R, S\})$. This means that the result of the $\delta$ function is:
answer: The new tape symbol that will be written on the current tape
Move the head after writing the symbol
choices: The new tape symbol that will be written on the current tape
Move the head after writing the symbol
Move the head before writing the symbol

q0.description: A Turing machine is formally defined as $(Q, \Sigma, \Gamma, q_0, F, \delta)$.
q0.question: What is $q_0$?

sigma.description: A Turing machine is formally defined as $(Q, \Sigma, \Gamma, q_0, F, \delta)$.
sigma.question: What is $\Sigma$?

sigma2.description: A Turing machine is formally defined as $(Q, \Sigma, \Gamma, q_0, F, \delta)$.
sigma2.question: What is $\Sigma$ for the machine in the left?

gamma.description: A Turing machine is formally defined as $(Q, \Sigma, \Gamma, q_0, F, \delta)$.
gamma.question: What is $\Gamma$?

gamma2.description: A Turing machine is formally defined as $(Q, \Sigma, \Gamma, q_0, F, \delta)$.
gamma2.question: What is $\Gamma$ for the machine in the left?

reg.description:
Here is an example of a machine that is slightly more complicated. This Turing machine accepts the language $L(a^*b^*c^*)$.

$M = (Q, Σ, Γ, s, F, δ)$
• $Q = \{q_0, q_1, q_2, q_3\}$,
• $Σ = \{a, b, c\}$,
• $Γ = Σ ∪ \{\#\} $,
• $s = q_0$,
• $F = q_2$,
• $δ = $
         ---------------------------------
          $q$     $Γ$     $(q, Γ, \{L, R, S\})$
         ---------------------------------
          $q_0$   $a$      $(q_0, a, R)$
          $q_0$   $b$      $(q_1, b, R)$
          $q_0$   $c$      $(q_2, c, R)$
          $q_0$   $\#$     $(q_3, \#, S)$
          $q_1$   $b$      $(q_1, b, R)$
          $q_1$   $c$      $(q_2, c, R)$
          $q_1$   $\#$     $(q_3, \#, S)$
          $q_2$   $c$      $(q_2, c, R)$
          $q_2$   $\#$     $(q_3, \#, S)$
reg.question: What is the type of this language?

nochange.description:
Here is an example of a machine that is slightly more complicated. This Turing machine accepts the language $L(a^*b^*c^*)$.

$M = (Q, Σ, Γ, s, F, δ)$
• $Q = \{q_0, q_1, q_2, q_3\}$,
• $Σ = \{a, b, c\}$,
• $Γ = Σ ∪ \{\#\} $,
• $s = q_0$,
• $F = q_2$,
• $δ = $
         ---------------------------------
          $q$     $Γ$     $(q, Γ, \{L, R, S\})$
         ---------------------------------
          $q_0$   $a$      $(q_0, a, R)$
          $q_0$   $b$      $(q_1, b, R)$
          $q_0$   $c$      $(q_2, c, R)$
          $q_0$   $\#$     $(q_3, \#, S)$
          $q_1$   $b$      $(q_1, b, R)$
          $q_1$   $c$      $(q_2, c, R)$
          $q_1$   $\#$     $(q_3, \#, S)$
          $q_2$   $c$      $(q_2, c, R)$
          $q_2$   $\#$     $(q_3, \#, S)$
nochange.question: Does the machine change the tape content while processing language strings?
correctFeedback: Look carefully at the transitions. In every case, the input symbol and the output symbol are the same.
incorrectFeedback: Look carefully at the transitions. In every case, the input symbol and the output symbol are the same.

abca.description:
Here is the graphical view of the machine.

Let us see how this machine will accept/reject strings
Let us start with the string $abc$.
abca.question: What is the result of $\delta(q_0, a)$?

abcb.description:
Let us see how this machine will accept/reject strings
Let us start with the string $abc$.
abcb.question: What is the result of $\delta(q_0, b)$?

abcc.description:
Let us see how this machine will accept/reject strings
Let us start with the string $abc$.
abcc.question: What is the result of $\delta(q_1, c)$?

abcend.description:
Let us see how this machine will accept/reject strings
Let us start with the string $abc$.
abcend.question: What is the result of $\delta(q_2, \#)$?

abcfinal.description:
Let us see how this machine will accept/reject strings
Let us start with the string $abc$.
abcfinal.question: The machine will accept the string as the machine entered a final state.

abaca.description:
Let us see how this machine will accept/reject strings
What about the string $abac$?
abaca.question: What is the result of $\delta(q_0, a)$?

abacb.description:
Let us see how this machine will accept/reject strings
What about the string $abac$?
abacb.question: What is the result of $\delta(q_0, b)$?

abaca2.description:
Let us see how this machine will accept/reject strings
What about the string $abac$?
abaca2.question: What is the result of $\delta(q_1, a)$?
abaca2.answer: There is no transition for $\delta(q_1, a)$
choices: There is no transition for $\delta(q_1, a)$

fail.description:
Let us see how this machine will accept/reject strings
What about the string $abac$?
fail.question: What will happen?
fail.answer: The machine will halt by following an undefined transition. So the string is rejected
choices: The machine will halt by following an undefined transition. So the string is rejected
The machine will try other transitions
